Posts.Content: Thanks DjinTonic did you get treated for your BPH? My former uro ignores my BPH and prostatitis to significantly influence my rising PSA, as he was pushing for biopsy. He is more worried that I really have cancer thus, he ordered bone scan and PET scan even before cancer was diagnosed although I don't blame him because clinical practice guidelines suggest my situation suggests higher probability for cancer. Meanwhile, my urinary symptoms have been resolved with prostate diet and supplements. However, as my BPH progresses to mild to moderate in 2 years, I'm thinking of trying the anti-BPH medication on my next visit with my new uro. See how we go.

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA, Biopsy with HGPIN

Posts.Content: Good day all. I had my 2nd biopsy last month showing 3 cores ASAP (small foci of atypical glands suspicious but not diagnostic of carcinoma) and 2 cores HGPIN out of 30 cores, 1 with adjacent ASAP. This was instigated 2 years ago as I was having urinary symptoms (frequency, urgency, nocturia) for some years, I was referred to urologist due to rising psa (9.5 July 2015, 32 June and Dec 2016, 46 March 2017, 33 May 2017, 39 July 2017). Results of multiparametric 3T MRI done 2 years ago were 'PIRADS 2, peripheral zone prostatitis, mild BPH on central gland with prostate volume 30cc, no lesions'. Repeat MRI done this year before my 2nd biopsy showed same 'PIRADS rating 2, no focal lesions, but with moderate prostatomegaly with BPH in central gland, prostate volume 49cc, PZ prostatitis'. Due to rising psa, my first transperineal saturation biopsy was done on Aug 2016 with all 36 cores benign, bone scan and PET scan using gallium 68 PSMA done early this year showed no metastasis. However, my rapid psa velocity (rising 4 times in a year), free psa 4.3 and phi (prostate health index) 97.6 suggest most likely aggressive carcinoma progression. Throughout this time, I am not treated for prostatitis, BPH and noncarcinomic biopsy. I am 57 years old, 72kg, with healthy lifestyle, no other medical issues and no family history of cancer. I am seeing my urologist in 2 weeks time to discuss my recent biopsy diagnosis. Thanks a lot, would really appreciate your thoughts of this. John

Posts.Title: Elevated PSA, Biopsy with HGPIN

Posts.Content: Thanks. I'm thinking of duodart, a combo pill of dutasteride and tamlosin. I think, at my age, I'm not worried of the side effects although down the line, my psa will alter in future tests.
Posts.Title: Elevated PSA, Biopsy with HGPIN

Posts.Content: Thanks and really appreciate your input, ASAdvocate. I, too in a diagnostic dilemma as all indicators cry out for somehow a prostate cancer to pop out. I am very adamant to have another biopsy in 3-6 months as suggested by my recent biopsy results although I might consider it after a year depending on my PSA (very eager what my uro says). I'm thinking mine is a continuum progression from enlarged prostate and prostatitis to low grade to high PIN and ASAP to full blown prostate cancer in some point in time. Meanwhile, I'm on a 'chemoprevention' diet. Again, I really appreciate to hear from others if they have same experience as mine. Thanks, John
Posts.Title: Elevated PSA, Biopsy with HGPIN

Posts.Content: Thanks, DjinTonic. That was my thinking, too. I purposefully delayed my 1st biopsy for a year against my uro's advice because my 1st MRI that was done a year before indicated no cancer (Note: 3T MRI has 90% accuracy to detect clinically significant prostate cancer). Also, a very rapid PSA rise (and fluctuating PSA values) are more indicative of BPH and inflammation than a slow and steady PSA rise typical for PCa.
